title: How to Clean Brushed Stainless Steel

steps.title: Start with water.
steps.content: Start with water. For basic spills, just plain water will do the trick. Use a soft rag, and apply warm water to the surface. You can use this method to wipe up spills, as well as small stains. Wipe with clear water once the stain is up. [2] X Research source Deionized water is a great option as well. [3] X Expert Source Susan Stocker Cleaning Guru Expert Interview. 8 November 2019.

steps.title: Wipe in the direction of the grain.
steps.content: Wipe in the direction of the grain. If you look closely at the surface of brushed stainless steel, you'll notice it has a grain. It's important to wipe with the grain, rather than against it. If you wipe against the grain, you can end up damaging the surface. [4] X Research source

steps.title: Avoid abrasiveness.
steps.content: Avoid abrasiveness. Anything that's too abrasive can scratch the surface of brushed stainless steel. That includes abrasive sponges and steel wool, but it also includes very hard water or gritty (dirty) water. [5] X Research source

steps.title: Wait until the appliance is cool.
steps.content: Wait until the appliance is cool. If you're cleaning an appliance like an oven, a stove or a toaster, it's a good idea to wait until it's cool before cleaning. Lightly touch the appliance. If it feels cool, it's fine to clean it. [6] X Research source

steps.title: Try stainless-steel specific products.
steps.content: Try stainless-steel specific products. Many products on the market are designed specifically for stainless steel. Because they are designed for stainless steel, they are more likely to keep your appliances looking sparkling. [7] X Expert Source Susan Stocker Cleaning Guru Expert Interview. 8 November 2019. You could try CLR for stainless steel, for instance.

steps.title: Use a glass cleaner.
steps.content: Use a glass cleaner. In some cases, a glass cleaner with ammonia may work on spills. Make sure to check for bleach before using them, as you don't want to apply bleach to stainless steel. [8] X Research source

steps.title: Skip products with chloride.
steps.content: Skip products with chloride. Products with chloride in them can be harmful to the surface of stainless steel, particularly brushed stainless steel. Therefore, you should avoid cleaners with bleach when working on these surfaces. [9] X Research source

steps.title: Avoid oven cleaners.
steps.content: Avoid oven cleaners. If the area is extra greasy or on the oven, you might be tempted to use an oven cleaner. However, oven cleaners are too abrasive for brushed stainless steel, so avoid applying them to this surface. [10] X Research source

steps.title: Use dish soap and water.
steps.content: Use dish soap and water. One way to keep your brushed stainless steel sparkling is to wipe it down often with a little soap and water. In fact, if you wipe it down when you're cooking or doing dishes, it will help you maintain the surface. Wipe off any soap when you're done, though, as you should only leave water on the surface. [11] X Research source

steps.title: Try vinegar.
steps.content: Try vinegar. Vinegar is a good natural solution for brushed stainless steel. Use a spray bottle to apply white vinegar to the surface. Follow up with a soft cloth, such as microfiber, always wiping in the direction of the grain. [12] X Research source

steps.title: Apply baking soda.
steps.content: Apply baking soda. Baking soda can remove tough stains, such as coffee. Use a soft wet rag to scrub with the baking soda, then wipe the baking soda away with a clean rag. Follow the grain. [13] X Research source You can also mix baking soda with dishwashing soap to make a paste and use that to scrub the surface. [14] X Research source

steps.title: Rinse the surface after using a cleaner.
steps.content: Rinse the surface after using a cleaner. No matter what product you use, make sure you rinse it off when you're done. You don't want any product to sit on the surface of the stainless steel, as it could damage the surface over time. [15] X Research source

steps.title: Dry the surface thoroughly.
steps.content: Dry the surface thoroughly. When water is left on brushed stainless steel, it can leave water stains on the surface. Therefore, use a soft cloth to dry off the water when you're done rinsing. [16] X Research source

steps.title: Add an oil for polish.
steps.content: Add an oil for polish. Mineral oil or olive oil are a good choice for this step. Oil helps polish the steel when you're done cleaning. It also protects the surface. Rub a little oil on with a soft cloth, making sure to wipe off any extra. [17] X Expert Source Susan Stocker Cleaning Guru Expert Interview. 8 November 2019. You can use an oil any time you clean your stainless steel, particularly if you're deep cleaning.

steps.title: Stick to one cleaner type.
steps.content: Stick to one cleaner type. You may be tempted to switch cleaners based on what's cheapest or what you have on hand. However, when it comes to stainless steel, it's best to stick to just one cleaner over time, as you won't have cleaners working against each other. [18] X Research source
